coredata.dc:title: Depolarization of light and pair—pair correlations of argon gas
coredata.dc:creator: Pinski, F.J.
Campbell, C.E.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A simple integral equation for the pair—pair correlation function of a fluid is solved for room temperature argon in the density range 1 to 600 amagat. It is used to calculate the depolarized intensity as a function of density and its sensitivity to the anisotropic pair polarizability. Good agreement with experiment is found at low density. Semi-quantitative agreement is obtained up to 600 amagat.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 56. number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 May 1978 DEPOLARIZATION OF LIGHT AND PAIR-PAIR CORRELATIONS OF ARGON GAS F.J. PINSKI + andC.E. CAMPBELL School of Physics and Astronomy, University of Minnesota, Minneapolis. Minnesota 55455. USA Received 10 February 1978 A simple integral equation for the pair—pair correlation function of a fluid is solved for room temperature argon in the density range 1 to 600 amagat. It is used to calculate the depolarized intensity as a function of density and its sensitivity to the anisotropic pair polarizabflity. Good agreemen-; with experiment is found at low density. Semi-quantitative agreement is obtained up to 600 amagat. 1. Introduction The depolarized light scattered from simple fluids provides information about the correlation between two pairs of particles in the fluid and about the cou- pling between the fluid and light. The depolarized in- tensity is given by [1] ID -f0(xW(y)P(x,y)Y^(x)Y^(y) dxdy , (1) where f3(r) is the anisotropic pair polarizability which describes the coupling of light to the fluid, and F(x,y) is the pair—pair correlation function: N N P(x,y)=N-^ T, [<s0c-ry)o0'-^)> l^f fC-r-l -<5(x-ry)X5(y-ry)>] , (2) where the thermal average is denoted by < >. P(x,y) is the correlated probability of finding a pair separated by x with finding a pair separated byy (the uncorre- lated probabilities are subtracted). Neither <3(r) nor * Research supported in part by the National Science Founda- tion under grant DMR 76-14777. * Present address: Department of Physics, State University of New York at Stony Brook, Stony Brook, New York 11794. USA. P(x,y) is well known for any nontrivial system. A simple integral equation is presented in this note for the pair—pair correlation function along with an investigation of the density dependence of the depo- larization ratio and its sensitivity to the details ofp(r). For room temperature argon, good agreement with the experimental results [2,3] is found at densities smaller than 200 amagat. Semi-qualitative agreement is found for the remaining part of the investigated den- sity range (up to 600 amagat). The results are sensitive to the form ofp(r), with the one provided by Oxtoby and Gelbart [4] giving the best agreement with exper- iment. The next section contains a discussion of the pair- pair correlation function and our approximate integral equation for this function. These pair—pair correla- tions are used in section 3 to obtain the depolarization ratio. A summary is presented in section 4 with a dis- cussion of other prospective calculations. 2. The pair—pair correlation function The pair—pair correlation function, as defined in eq. (2), is used to determine the joint thermal average of a pair of two-body operators: <Aff>-C4><B>= \Nfa(x)b(y)P(x,y) dx dy , (3) 156 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 May 1978 Volume 56, number 1 where N A = S aOy) i-</ and N B=Zi &(ry). i<l Z=/dr,...d^exp[g-^]. (7) The pair distribution function is then expressed as a functional derivative An example is given by the equation for the depolar- ized intensity in eq. (1). P(x,y) is a linear combination of two, three and four particle distribution functions for the fluid as shown in its definition. This combina- tion is much simpler than either the three- or four- body distribution functions because it is relatively easy to approximate, and the information contained in P is easily displayed in terms of its Legendre expan- sion, with each coefficient depending only on the two scalar quantities, JC andy. These advantages have been obtained at the cost of losing some of the infor- mation inherent in the usual three- and four-body dis- tribution functions by integrating over some coordi- nates. The depolarized intenisty, however, depends only on the 1=2 coefficient in the Legendre expan- sion of P. All of the explicit three- and four-body correla- tions in P are obtained by subtracting the self-correla- tion of all pairs of particles, Le., the terms where (i, j) = (k, I) or (/, fe) in eq. (2). The remainder is de- fined to be p^H, where pH(x,y) = P(x,y)/p -g(x)[8(x-i-y) +8(x-y)] . (4) The radial distribution function g(x) in this notation can be written as (5) with p being defined as the number density of the fluid. The binary collision approximation has been used in the theory of the depolarized intensity at low den- sity; it is equivalent to setting H to zero, i.e., elimi- nating all three- and four-body correlations [5]. With- in the binary collision approximation, P is given by ^.C^y) = Pg(x)[S(x -i-JO + 5(x -y)] . (6) To improve upon this approximation, we have devel- oped a scheme which uses the partition function Z as a generating functional for the correlation functions [6]. In the canonical ensemble, the partition function is given in terms of the two-body potential Vaad the temperature T by g(x) =(-2keT/Np) 8 In Z/5 V(x) . (8) The pair—pair distribution function is proportional to the second functional derivative of In Z and can be written as P(x, y) = [4(kQ r)2/JVp2 ] 5 2 in Z/8 V(x)8 V(y) (9a) =(-2ksT/p}8g(x)/8V(y) . (9b) An immediate consequence is that any analytic ap-. proximation for g in terms of V caa be functionally differentiated, giving an approximation for P. The only such approximation fora- which is known to give P the symmetry in x andy implicit in eqs. (2) and (9a) is the hypemetted chain equation (HNC) [7]. The re- sulting approximation (oTP(x,y) is best expressed by an integral equation forff(x,y)'. fl(x,y) =g(xjg(y)[M(x+y) +M(x -y)] -l-pg(x)fdzM(x-z)H(z,y), (10) where M is defined as M(r) =N-1 Z) [1 - \IS\k)} e^"- (11) * and where S(k), the liquid structure function, is written in terms ofg(r) as S(k) = I +pfdr{g(r) - 1] e-*"-- (12) This linear integral equation for H separates into a set of decoupled equations for each Legendre coefficient which depends only on the magnitudes ofjc andy. These coefficients are defined by H(x,y) = Z) [(2/+ l)/4ir] H,(x,y) , 3>,(cos 0) , (13) where '3>^ is the /th Legendre polynomial and 0 is the angle between x and y. For room temperature argon, we have solved for the / = 0 and (' == 2 coefficients at a number of densities between 1 and 600 amagat. A Lennard—Jones 6—12 po- tential was used with a = 3.41 A, E/kyT= 0.41 and 157 Volume 56, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 May 1978 Fig. 1. Contour plots of/=0 and 7=2 Legendre projections of H(x,y)IN for argon at T = 293 K and p = 400 amagat. T= 293 K. The HNC equation was used to calculate g(r) and S(k). Contour plots of the / = 0 and /= 2 re- sults at 400 amagat are displayed in fig. 1. Since the expansion coefficients in eq. (13) are symmetric in x andy, only half of each function has been displayed. The diagonal part (x =y) of these two coefficients at several densities is shown in fig. 2. The most signifi- cant feature of these results is a large negative extrem- um on the diagonal near 3.6 A, which is comparable to the distance at which g(r) attains a maximum due to nearest neighbors. Since H contains three- and four- body correlations, the minimum in H is at least partly due to regions around a pair where another particle is excluded because of geometric considerations. Also note that the 7=2 coefficient is remarkably insensi- -18. Fig. 2. The diagonal part (x =y) of the / = 0 (a) and I =2 Os) Legendre projections vifH(y,y){N at T= 293 K for three densities: ——. 400 amagat; ——, 200 amagat; and -.-.-., 100 amagat. 158 tive to changes in the density in the range of 100 to 400 amagat. 3. The depolarization ratio The depolarization ratio A is the depolarized inten- sity TQ divided by the Brillouin intensity /g and can be expressed as A^n/^B^/lSao-S'CO)] X fdxdy^x)P(y)P(x,y)Y^x)Y^(y), (14) where (XQ is the atomic polarizabuity and where S(0)= S(k ->• 0) which is known in terms of the compressibil- ity and temperature [8]. The form offS(r) for point dipoles is PQm(r)=6a^r3, (15) which has been used as an approximation for fS(r) at all distances for fluids composed of real particles. While this form is exact at large r, short range correc- tions reflecting the atomic structure are important and have been calculated by Oxtoby and Gelbart [4]. These results are parametrized in the form ^OG^) = ^DroO-) - A exp(-r/B) , (16) withA = 172 A3 and B = 0.477 A and QQ = 1.64 A3. The calculated and experimental [2,3] values of A are shown in fig. 3 as a plot of A/p as a function ofp den- sities less than 120 amagat. Three features are worth noting. First, the intercept on this plot (which is the slope ofA(p) at zero density) is the only point where the binary collision approximation and the HNC ap- proximation coincide. Significant corrections to the binary collision approximation exist even at very low density. A second feature is the sensitivity of the re- sults to the form of0(r); the result which uses 0QG falls below the calculation using ^nro ^Y shout 40%. Finally, the result using (SQQ is in fairly good agree- ment with the experiment of McTague et al. [3]; how- ever, better agreement with Thibeau's experiment [2] is obtained by using 0r»ID- The calculated and experimental results over the density range p ^ 600 amagat are shown in figs. 4 and 5. Pig. 4 is a plot of the depolarization ratio given in 15 May 1978 Volume 56, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS Fig. 3. Low density behavior of the depolarization ratio di- vided by the density [A/p, eq. (14)]. The experimental re- sults ofThibeau [2] are denoted by X, those of McTague et aL [3] denoted by dashes. The dot-dash line is the binary col- lision approximation with eq. (15) for 0(r) [eq. (6)]. and the solid lines are the hypemetted chain approximation [eq. (10)] with two different approximations for the anisotropic pair polarizability [P(r)l: DID [eq. (15)] and OG [eq. (16)1. eq. (14). It shows a monotonic increase in A with in- creasing density. At high densities, the increase is pri- marily due to the decreasing amount of the Brillouin intensity (in the denominator of A). The Brillouin scattering is removed by multiplying A by 155(0), producing a quantity proportional to IQ which is plotted in fig. 5. Note that /p reaches a maximum between 200 and 300 amagat, and at 600 amagat, it falls to a value comparable to its value at 100 amagat. At very low density (<10 amagat), the binary col- lision model is a good approximation. As the density is increased, this model fails; at 140 amagat it gives re- sults which are a factor of 2 greater than experiment. The HNC approximation brackets the experimental 200 400 600 Density [Amagat] -ff Fig. 4. The depolarization ratio A(p) labeled as in fig. 3 ex- cept that the dashed curve is the experiment of ref. [2]. The molecular dynamics results of Alder et aL [8] are labeled by o. 0 200 400 600 Density [ Amagat 1 Fig. 5. The depolarization intensity/D = l5S(0)A, labeled as in figs. 3 and 4. result of Thibeau- When 0Dn> was "sed, a result above the experiment was obtained and with PQQ, the result was below. The discrepancy between the two experi- ments at low density suggests a rather large uncertain- ty at all densities. Therefore, the sensitivity of/p to the choice ofp(r) can be considered as a major feature of the theoretical result. 4. Discussion The consideration of depolarized light scattering from simple fluids has led to a study of correlations involving more particles than the well-studied two- body correlations embodied in the radial distribution function. Unfortunately, the experimental informa- tion about higher-order correlations is somewhat ob- scured by the uncertainty in t3(r), the coupling func- tion between the fluid and light. Some assessment can be made of the validity of the HNC approximation in- dependent of the choice offS(r). It is well-known, for example, that approximations forg(r) such as HNC and the Percus—Yevick approximation are increasing- ly accurate as the density is lowered. The same is ex- pected to be true for the HNC approximation for P(x,y), so that our results should be very good at low density (sSlOO amagat). This suggests the possibility of determining 0(r) in conjunction with experimental results. On the other hand, the HNC results are certainly in error at high densities (>300 amagat). Our experience in several calculations o{g(r) is that the results ob- tained at some density p are more characteristic of a higher density, p'. This suggests that scaling the theo- 159 Volume 56, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 May 1978 retical results in fig. 5 would improve the agreement between the experiment and the calculation which usedpoG- The error introduced into our results by the HNC approximation can be subjected to a direct test by comparing to the essentially exact molecular dynamics results for simple fluids obtained by Alder et al. [8]. One of their calculations corresponds to room temper- ature argon at 570 amagat using the same Lennard— Jones potential. A separate calculation ofP(x,y) is not made, but instead A is calculated directly using ^DID Ior ^le anisotropic pair polarizability. Their re- sults are exact for the system with the potential and fS that were chosen, and are a standard for assessing all approximations. It is seen in figs. 4 and 5 that their value of A lies about 10% above our approximate re- sults for the same system. A similar shift in our results which use (?QG would give better agreement with ex- periment. The HNC and molecular dynamics results can be viewed as complemsntary. HNC is valid in the low den- sity regime where molecular dynamics is not a feasible method. Furthermore, HNC provides a quick, inexpen- sive semi-quantitative survey of higher densities which could be used to investigate the sensitivity of A to p(r) and other parameters, such as the temperature and two-body potential. Our method of generating the approximation — by functional variation of an approximation for g(r) — lends itself to obvious refinement. The symmetry re- quirement on P(x,y) could be relaxed. The Percus— Yevick (PY) approximation, or perhaps a symmetrized version ofPY could be used, or several other approxi- mations could be explored. In solving the HNC approximation forP [eq. (10)], we have always used the HNC approximation foig(x) as input. Somewhat different results would be ex- pected if the PY approximation or some other, per- haps better, approximation for g had been used. Since the potential does not explicitly appear in the integral equation for P [eq. (10)] any g(r) and S(k) could have been used — including ones obtained from experiment, if available. Finally, it should be re-emphasized that with suffi- cient computing resources, P(x,y) can be obtained ex- actly using molecular dynamics or Monte Carlo inte- gration techniques. We have written an algorithm for calculating projections ofP and have applied it to liquid ^He [9], where we find semi-quantitative agree- ment between the HNC approximation and the Monte Carlo results. Furthermore, by using the time depen- dent generalization ofP we hope to be able to use mo- lecular dynamics to discover the frequency depen- dence ofP(x,y,t). The importance of such a calcula- tion lies in the fact that this function (or its Fourier transform) plays a role in second-order light scattering comparable to the role played by the dynamic struc- ture function S(k. <«?) in inelastic neutron scattering and Brillouin scattering. Moreover, because of the ex- tended nature of^(r), it is not actually possible to ex- perimentally separate this higher-order correlation function from the interaction with light. The impor- tance of molecular dynamics computer experiments is thus enhanced as the most direct probe of higher- order correlation functions. Acknowledgement We would like to acknowledge numerous helpful discussions with J.W. Halley, P. Kleban and J. McTague. References [1] W.M. Gelbart, Advan. Chem. Phys. 26 (1974) 1. [2] M. Thibeau, B. [5] W.M. Gelbart, J. Chem. Phys. 57 (1972) 699. [6] J.K. Percus, in: The equilibrium theory of classical fluids, eds. Frish and Lebowitz (Benjamin, New York, 1964); G. Stell, in: Phase transitions and critical phenomena, Vol. 5B, eds. C. Domb and M. Green (Academic Press, New York, 1975) ch. 3. [7] C.E. CampbeD, in: Progress in liquid physics, ed. C.A. Croxton (WBey, New York, 1977) ch. 6. [8] A. Michels, H. Wijker and H-K. Wijker, Physica 15 (1949) 627; A.L. Gosman, R.D. McCarty and J.G. Strauss, Phys. Rev. A7 (1973)281. 160 ture argon at 570 amagat using the same Lennard— Jones potential. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A simple integral equation for the pair—pair correlation function of a fluid is solved for room temperature argon in the density range 1 to 600 amagat. It is used to calculate the depolarized intensity as a function of density and its sensitivity to the anisotropic pair polarizability. Good agreement with experiment is found at low density. Semi-quantitative agreement is obtained up to 600 amagat.
